item.title: Bases for Topologies
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $X$ be a set. To specify a topology on $X$, one needs to give a complete description of its open sets, but in practice, certain subcollections suffice. Two questions arise: If $\mc{T}$ is a given topology on $X$, what subcollections $\mc{B}\subseteq\mc{T}$ completely specify $\mc{T}$? What kinds of collections $\mc{B}\subseteq\pow(X)$ can specify some topology $\mc{T}$ on $X$? In either case, we say that $\mc{T}$ is generated by $\mc{B}$.

item.title: Fixed-point Theorems for p-groups
item.description: Non-triviality of $Z(G)$ A standard method to study a finite group is to first find its center; if non-trivial, we can set up an induction proof my successively quotienting by $Z(G)$. This is indeed the case for finite $p$-groups, which we now show. Throughout, let $G$ be a non-trivial finite $p$-group. Lemma. If $G$ acts on a finite set $S$, then $\l|Z\r|\equiv\l|S\r|\,\mod\,p$ where $Z$ is the set of fixed-points of this action.

item.title: Cayley’s Theorem
item.description: Motivation & Statement Whenever one encounters a type of mathematical object, one should ask if there is an associated ‘representation theorem’. Such a theorem for groups is as follows. Theorem (Cayley). Every group $G$ is a subgroup of a symmetry group. Proof. Click to expand... We show that the left-multiplication action $\phi:G\to\Aut G$ is faithful, for then $G\substructeq\Aut G$. Indeed, if $\phi(g_1)=\phi(g_2)$, then we have $\phi(g_1)g=\phi(g_2)g$ for all $g\in G$. That is, we have $g_1g=g_2g$, so $g_1=g_2$ as desired.

item.title: Filter
item.description: Motivation & Definition Definition. Let $P$ be a poset. A filter on $P$ is a subset $\em\neq F\subseteq P$ such that (Upward-closure). If $p\in F$ and $q\geq p$, then $q\in F$. (Downward-directed). If $p_1,p_2\in F$, then there exists $q\in F$ with $q\leq p_1,p_2$.

item.title: Equivalence Relation
item.description: Motivation & Definition Oftentimes, we wish to regard two objects as ‘being the same’ (for instance, two sets are ‘the same’ if they have the same cardinality), despite them not being equal. The concept of an equivalence relation can be thought of as a generalization of equality. Definition. Let $X$ be a set. An equivalence relation on $X$ is a (binary) relation $E\subseteq X^2$ subject to the following conditions. (Reflexive). For all $x\in X$, we have $(x,x)\in E$.

item.title: Subgroup
item.description: Definition and Generation A standard method of studying an object $-$ in this case, a group $G$ $-$ is to analyze other groups that ‘sit inside’ $G$. This is formalized in the following Definition. Let $G$ be a group. A subgroup of $G$ is a subset $H\subseteq G$ equipped with a group structure making the inclusion $H\into G$ a group homomorphism. We write $H\substructeq G$ to indicate that $H$ is a subgroup of $G$.

item.title: Ideal
item.description: To study the quotient objects in a category, we must first understand the congruence relations in said category. For $\catring$, these are in correspondence with ideals. Definition. Let $R$ be a ring. A (left) ideal in $R$ is a subgroup $(\mf{a},+)\substructeq R$ such that $r\mf{a}\subseteq\mf{a}$ for all $r\in R$. Similarly for right ideals and two-sided ideals.

item.title: Ring
item.description: Motivation & Definition The concept of a ring naturally arises when studying the endomorphism group of an Abelian group $G$. Indeed, $\End G$ is itself Abelian $-$ but more importantly, it has an extra operation of composition. These operations are compatible in the sense of: Definition. A ring is a tuple $(R,+,\cdot,1)$ where $(R,\cdot,1)$ is a monoid, $(R,+)$ is an Abelian group, and where for all $r,s,t\in R$, we have $$\begin{equation} (r+s)\cdot t=r\cdot t+s\cdot t\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathit{and}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ t\cdot(r+s)=t\cdot r+t\cdot s.

item.title: Finite Group
item.description: Let $G$ be a group. The condition that (the underlying set of) $G$ is finite allows us to apply methods from finite combinatorics to analyze $G$. We give some group-theoretic frameworks for which such combinatorics can be applied to. Such methods can become incredibly sophisticated; for instance, the classification of finite simple groups is one of the major achievements of mathematics. We only touch on the very very basics here.

item.title: Order
item.description: Definition. Let $G$ be a group. An element $x\in G$ is has finite order if we have $x^n=e$ for some $n>0$; the least such $n$ is the order of $x$, denoted $\ord x$. Otherwise, set $\ord x\coloneqq\infty$, and say that $x$ has infinite order. Remark. More abstractly, for a fixed $x\in G$, consider the map $\phi_x:\Z\to G$ induced uniquely by sending $1\mapsto x$, and set $\ord x\coloneqq\l|\im\phi_x\r|$. If $\ker\phi_x=n\Z$ for some $n>0$, then $\im\phi_x\iso\Z/n\Z$ has cardinality $n$.

item.title: Cyclic Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition The simplest class of groups are the so-called cyclic groups, which are those that are generated by a single element. Definition. A group $G$ is said to be cyclic if $G=\gen{x}$ $^\dagger$ for some $x\in G$. Classification Let $G=\gen{x}$ be cyclic. By definition, $\phi:\Z\to G$ sending $m\mapsto x^m$ is surjective. Depending on the order $n\coloneqq\ord x$ of $x$, $G$ takes on the following forms. If $1\leq n<\infty$, then $\ker\phi=n\Z$ and hence $G\iso\Z/n\Z$.

For every functor $F:C\to\catset$ and every object $c\in C$, we have a bijection $$\begin{equation} y\coloneqq y_{F,c}:\Hom(C(c,\slot),F)\to Fc\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathit{sending}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \big(\eta:C(c,\slot)\to F\big)\mapsto\eta_c1_c, \end{equation}$$ which is moreover natural in both $F$ and $c$. Proof (Bijection). Click to expand... item.description: Motivation & Definition Universal Arrows Definition. Let $F:D\to C$ be a functor and fix $c\in C$. A universal arrow from $c$ to $F$ is an initial object in $(c\downto F)$. That is, it is a pair $(r,u)$, with $r\in D$ and $u:c\to Fr$, inducing for each $d\in D$ a bijection $$\begin{equation} \phi_d:D(r,d)\to C(c,Fd):f’\mapsto Ff’\circ u. \end{equation}$$ This can be visualized as in the following diagram. Remark.
